bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to J.H.L. Cumpston, June 16, 1923

div1.p: Carter asks Cumpston to insert the enclosed note at the beginning of Carter's article “The Chance of the Extension of Yellow Fever to Asia and Australia.”

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to J.H.L. Cumpston, June 16, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Australia
------- F. F. Russell,
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C. U. S. A.,
June 16, 1923.
Dr. J. H. L. Cumpston,
Department of Health,
51 Spring Street,
Melbourne, Australia.
Dear Doctor Cumpston:
div1.p:
I would be glad if you would be kind enough to insert the accom-
ing note, as the beginning of the section on Africa in my article on
“The Chance of the Extension of Yellow Fever to Asia and Australia”
mailed you a few days ago.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General (retired.) Enclosure.

div1.p:
The writer knows nothing of Africa at first hand. He can only
judge of the conditions there from the reports (verbal and written)
of others. Yet as this study would be otherwise entirely incomplete
he is submitting deductions from such knowledge as he has of the
yellow fever in Africa. He believes these deductions are justified
as a conservative interpretation of the facts as reported.

To begin Section on Africa in “The Chance of the Extension of
Yellow Fever to Asia and Australia,” by H. R. Carter.
